I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  Since its launch in 2012, ADB’s Supply Chain Finance Program (SCFP) has supported 
1,059 transactions valued at $722 million. Of the 1,059 transactions, 864 transactions involve 
SMEs. SCFP has also generated $361 million in co-financing as of 31 October 2018. The SCFP 
continues to expand in view of the additional financing and broader scope approved in 2018.1 As 
the strategic direction of SCFP was widened from large global banks to include banks in DMCs, 
pipeline development is ongoing with DMC-based partner financial institutions (PFIs), with initial 
candidates  to  be  identified  through  ADB’s  Trade  Finance  Program  (TFP)  partner  bank 
relationships. Going forward, SCFP is also assessing the extension of debt financing directly to 
corporate and SME obligors without the involvement of a PFI and working with third-party SCF 
platforms. These are expected to further widen SCFP’s reach both geographically, to focus on 
more challenging markets, and with SMEs. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
2.  This is the first subproject under the Capacity Development for the Supply Chain Finance 
Program (Phase 2). 
 
B.  Subproject Scope  
3.  Subproject 1 will provide the SCFP with funding to conduct due diligence and monitoring 
assessments on DMC companies, DMC banks and PFIs, administer transactions and manage 
overall counterparty relationships. Subproject 1 will also include capacity building through in- 
house capacity development as well as seminars and trainings.  
 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
4.  Output 1: SCF availability expanded in DMCs. Under subproject 1, ADB will engage 
consultants who will assist in the implementation of the SCFP by conducting in-depth due 
diligence and risk analysis on DMC companies in which ADB would assume risk under the 
program, administering transactions, performing monitoring assessments on DMC companies, 
DMC banks and PFIs, and ensuring that two additional supply chain finance agreements with 
PFIs are executed by Q4 2018.  
 
5.  Output  2:    SCF  knowledge  deepened  in  DMCs  through  in-house  capacity 
development as well as seminars and trainings. Subproject 1 will fund related knowledge-
sharing and partnership activities including in-house capacity development training, seminars and 
regional trainings for DMC banks, SMEs and regulators to increase supply chain finance usage 
and broaden SME access to supply chain financing. The consultants will also help design and 
implement a supply chain finance study in collaboration with the ADB Institute, ADB’s Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department, and the International Chamber of Commerce to 
establish industry benchmarks. These activities will contribute to the development of supply chain 
finance in countries where it is still at a nascent stage of development. 
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. Proposed Loans, Guarantees, and Risk Participation Products for Additional Financing Supply Chain 
Finance Program. Manila.

2   
6.  Output 3: Gender initiatives implemented for SCFP. SCFP will encourage female 
participants in all its seminars, trainings and capacity development activities. 
 
7.  Subproject 1 activities will include the following: 
 
(i)  work with DMC companies (i.e. corporate and SME obligors) and PFIs to acquire 
financial data; 
(ii)  conduct in-depth due diligence and risk analysis that will focus on credit and 
performance risk and established relationships specific to a supply chain of DMC 
companies in which ADB would assume risk under the program, and ensure that 
business  activities  of  such  DMC  companies  are  not  on  ADB’s  prohibited 
investment activities list; 
(iii)  assess  the  SCF  operations  capacity  of  selected  banks  and  make 
recommendations for improvement; 
(iv)  draft credit applications, risk ratings, and financial due diligence reports; 
(v)  conduct integrity due diligence and reputational risk reviews, including monitoring 
and following up on recommendations for improvement;  
(vi)  conduct signing ceremonies with new PFIs;  
(vii)  conduct  knowledge-building,  knowledge-sharing,  and  partnership-development 
activities (including training seminars for DMC banks, SMEs and regional training 
and/or networking events);  
(viii)  administer transactions and perform annual monitoring assessments on DMC 
companies and PFIs; and 
(ix)  engage consultants or possibly work with established financial technology or SCF 
platforms to facilitate operations. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
8.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $1,566,667 of which (i) $1,166,667 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF)- Others and (ii) $400,000 
will be financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Special Fund 
(FSDPSF)2.  The funds will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem for international consultants, 
national consultants, conference related expenditures, and miscellaneous expenses. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
9.  ADB will administer the subproject. PSOD will select, supervise and evaluate consultants 
as well as resource persons that will be engaged for TFP seminars and trainings.
